markdown.markdown:
![](midterm_presentation_files/TeamLogo.png){fig-align="center" width="100%"} ## Research Question and Motivation ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} **Research Question** Identify which [predictors]{style="color:purple;"} (spatial, structural, and/or socio-economic) contribute to the most accurate model for the City's Automated Valuation Model ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} **Motivation** Residential property tax assessments have [equitable and financial]{style="color:purple;"} implications for homeowners as well as [fiscal]{style="color:purple;"} implications for the city ::: ::::: ![](midterm_presentation_files/Skyline.jpg){fig-align="center" width="100%"} ## Data Sources - [Property Sales]{style="color:purple;"} (Philadelphia, 2023-2024): City of Philadelphia - OpenDataPhilly - [Socio-Economics]{style="color:purple;"}: United States Census - American Community Survey - [Spatial Features]{style="color:purple;"}: City of Philadelphia - OpenDataPhilly ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](midterm_presentation_files/Census.png){fig-align="left" width="100%"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](midterm_presentation_files/CityofPhiladelphiaLogo.jpg){fig-align="right" width="100%"} ::: ::::: ## Spatial Distribution of Sale Prices in Philadelphia ::::: columns ::: {.column width="80%"} ![](midterm_presentation_files/salepricemap.png){fig-align="center" width="80%"} ::: ::: {.column width="20%"} - Higher sale prices are concentrated in [Central]{style="color:purple;"} and [Northwest]{style="color:purple;"} Philadelphia ::: ::::: ## Factors Impacting Sale Price ::::: columns ::: {.column width="80%"} ![](midterm_presentation_files/TLAbig.jpg){fig-align="center" width="80%"} ::: ::: {.column width="20%"} - There is a notable relationship between [sale price]{style="color:purple;"} and [total livable area]{style="color:purple;"} ::: ::::: ## Model Comparison | Model | RMSE | MAE | R² | |:--------|-----------:|----------:|------:| | Model 1 | 230,140.41 | 15,174.13 | 0.287 | | Model 2 | 215,430.39 | 90,217.97 | 0.380 | | Model 3 | 211,021.39 | 90,144.74 | 0.405 | | Model 4 | 196,081.17 | 71,582.45 | 0.490 | : Model Performance Metrics {.striped .hover tbl-left} - [Model 1]{style="color:purple;"} (Structural) and [Model 2]{style="color:purple;"} (Structural + Census) had the worst performance. - [Spatial features]{style="color:purple;"} (Model 3) and [interaction terms]{style="color:purple;"} (Model 4) boosted model performance. ## Top Predictors ::: {.column width="70%"} - In a wealthy neighborhood ($\beta$ = 50,306.450, p \< 0.01) - Number of bedrooms ($\beta$ = 33,544.290, p \< 0.01) - Number of bathrooms ($\beta$ = 29,510.940, p \< 0.01) ::: ## Model Performance ![](midterm_presentation_files/Final_Model_CV_Scatter.png){fig-align="center" width="100%"} ## Hardest to Predict - [Northeast]{style="color:purple;"} and [West]{style="color:purple;"} Philly are hardest to predict due to the low income neighborhood limitation of our model ![](midterm_presentation_files/median.png){fig-align="center" width="60%"} ## Recommendations ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="80%"} ::: ::: {.column width="20%" style="text-align:left;"} - Policymakers should be aware that houses in lower-income neighborhoods will not be accurately predicted by this model - Physical features of a structure such as the number of bedrooms/bathrooms serve as strong predictors of home sale price. Nearby attractive amenities such as proximity to transit stations as well as distance from crime also contribute. ::: ::: ![](midterm_presentation_files/houses.jpg){fig-align="center" width="80%"} ## Limitations & Next Steps **Limitations** - Philadelphia sale prices don't have a linear relationship, particularly among lower-priced homes - Variables used were aggregated and not weighted **Next Steps** - Update the model to account for lower neighborhoods and tailor spatial features to add texture and depth to the model ![](midterm_presentation_files/House.jpg){fig-align="center" width="80%"} ## Questions? [Thank you!]{style="color:purple;"} from Sujan, Henry, Ryan, Kavana, Chloe, and Nina :)

Contact us at: *inquiries@tnc.com* ![](midterm_presentation_files/TeamLogo.png){fig-align="center" width="100%"}
